metadata.case_name: Ram Pershad v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The assessee and his wife owned a large number of shares in a private limited company engaged in the business of running hotels.

By virtue of Art. 109 of the Articles of Association, the assessee became the first Managing Director on terms and conditions agreed to and embodied in an agreement dated November 20, 1955 between himself and the company.

Under the agreement, the assessee was to receive Rs. 2,000/- per month, a fixed sum of Rs. 500/p.m. as car allowance, 10 per cent of gross profits of the company and he and his wife were entitled to free board and lodging in the hotel.

For the assessment year 1956-57 for which the accounting year is the year ending 30th September 1955, the assessee was assessed in respect of Rs. 53,913/- payable to him as 10% of the gross profits of the company.

The assessee gave up the above amount soon after the accounts were finalised but before they were passed by the general meeting of the shareholders because the company would not be making net profits if the stipulated commission was paid to him.

The Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the Tribunal and the Delhi High Court held that the 10% commission on gross profits amounting to Rs. 53,913/- was taxable as salary under s. 7 of the Act and that the income had accrued to the assessee during the previous year.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 29, 1967 of the Delhi High Court in I. T. Reference No. 46-D of 1962.
Art. 109 provided that the assessee shall be the Managing Director for 20 years on terms and conditions embodied in the agreement.
Art. 136: subject to the agreement, general management in hands of Managing Director with specified powers.
Art. 137: Managing Director can sign receipts and cheques.
Art. 139: Managing Director allowed to work for and contract with the company as agent or manager on terms agreed with Directors.
Art. 140: additional powers, some subject to Board control.
Art. 141: charge and custody of property etc.
Art. 142: execute decisions of the Board, do necessary things for management.
Cl. k of agreement dated 29-11-1955: assessee can resign with 3 months notice; company can terminate if not diligent or not in interests of company.
This Court on November 9, 1971 directed Tribunal for supplementary statement on third question referring to Morvi Industries Ltd. v. CIT.
Tribunal in supplementary statement held no deduction u/s 10(1) or 10(2).

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 53,913/- was a revenue receipt of the assessee of the previous year?
Whether the amount is chargeable under s. 7 or s. 10 of the Income-tax Act?
If the amount is chargeable under section 10, is the assessee entitled to a deduction of Rs. 53,913/- under s.10(1) or s. 10(2)?

Whether the 10 per cent gross profits payable to the assessee under the terms of the agreement appointing him as the Managing Director is liable to be assessed as salary under s.7 or as income from business under s.10.

petitioner_arguments.text: The amount had not accrued to him in the accounting year; even if accrued, not taxable under s.7 or s.10.
To assess as salary, must be master-servant relationship with supervision and control; here, Managing Director is agent or independent contractor, not servant, so commission is business income.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Halsbury's Laws of England, Bowstead on Agency, Company Law treatises; s.7

respondent_arguments.text: The commission is taxable as salary under s.7; it accrued in the previous year.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.7 Income-tax Act 1922; Morvi Industries Ltd. v. CIT

court_reasoning.text: Test of supervision/control not universal; depends on nature of employment, articles, agreement. Managing Director can be servant if terms create such relationship.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctor, chauffeur examples show no day-to-day control needed for servant status.

court_reasoning.text: Articles and agreement show assessee employed as servant: powers from articles, subject to Board control, can be terminated for non-diligence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Control via articles and general meetings; executes Board decisions.

court_reasoning.text: Remuneration payable as salary under s.7.
Amount accrued in year of account per Morvi; revenue receipt not disputed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to consider other questions.

holdings.text: Rs. 53,913/- is revenue receipt of previous year; chargeable as salary under s.7, not s.10; no deduction under s.10(1) or (2).
Managing Director's remuneration under articles and agreement is salary as he is servant of company.

precedents_cited.case_name: Morvi Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Accrual of income in year of account; basis for supplementary statement.
Managing director has dual capacity; contract of service, not for services.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Manmohan Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Treasurer not servant despite office; control and supervision test.

precedents_cited.case_name: Piyare Lal Adishwar Lal v. Commr. of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: No single test for master-servant vs contractor; indicia listed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Qamar Shaffi Tyabji v. Commissioner of E.P.T., Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessee as delegate of trustees was agent, not servant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal v. Govt. of Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Managing agents not servants due to assignment, long term, commission, sub-delegation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Armstrong Smith
precedents_cited.relevance: Managing Director servant per articles; remuneration salary u/s7.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Nagi Reddy
precedents_cited.relevance: Managing Director's remuneration as business income considered.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dharangadhra Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Direct method: nature of work, control, supervision.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Salary includes commission; chargeability as salary vs business income; reference; deductions if business.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Board of Directors manage business, control and supervise.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed with costs. The commission of Rs. 53,913/- is held taxable as salary under s.7 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, having accrued in the previous year relevant to AY 1956-57.

key_quotes.text: "the managing director has two functions and capacities. Qua managing director he is a party to a contract with the company, and this contract is a contract of employment more specifically I am of opinion that it is a contract of service and not a contract for service."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Anderson case; supports MD as servant.

key_quotes.text: "We would therefore hold that the remuneration payable to him is salary."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the control and supervision is exercised and is exercisable in terms of the articles of association by the Board of Directors and the company in its general meeting."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains nature of control for MD.
